commit.message: Remove a few old TODO items
Fix a test under Python 2.7
Remove an old unused private function

Return to simpler str’s for satellites and topoi

While centralizing the vector naming logic has been an improvement, I
think that displaying the whole vector with `->` notation is a bit
verbose when someone just wants to print their Earth satellite object.
So let’s return to simple non-vector strings when printing them, or
printing Topos objects.

Further improvements to Apparent docstring

Following comments by @mkbrewer.

Major pivot of vector str() and repr() logic

The printed representations of vector functions were rather a mess and
had little consistency; most of them, for example, didn’t print both
their center and their target, but just their target.  So let’s now put
the master `VectorFunction` class in charge of how the string ultimately
look, and only ask the subclasses to weigh in on the details.  In
particular, this lets the new ReversedVector properly display itself as
the reverse of whatever the wrapped vector would normally do.
Add changelog entry about new strftime methods
Remove what looks to be an unnecessary check
Add support for correct microseconds in strftime()

Advertise ephemeris epoch dates & make printable

Add support for rending ephemeris initial and final epochs as Skyfield
Time objects.  And to make it easier to print them out, add strftime()
support for all of Skyfield’s major time scales.

Make Time whole and fraction have same dimensions

Otherwise, `.utc_jpl()` was dying with:
```
  File "/home/brandon/skyfield/skyfield/timelib.py", line 520, in utc_jpl
    return format % args
TypeError: %d format: a number is required, not numpy.ndarray
```

Clarify “Apparent” class vs “apparent place”

The class docstrings currently provide no clarification for a reader who
sees a class named `Apparent`, inspired by the Naval Observatory phrase
“apparent position”, and think instead of the usual concept of “apparent
place.”  So let’s provide some clarification, and while we’re at it,
help readers who might fall into these docs first with some idea of how
each class is usually generated in code.  Inspired by the discussion in

Remove an unused code path, and clarify some names

Turns out?  The `apparent()` method was never using its own
`self._observer_gcrs_au`, so let’s remove that case to simplify.  (Also,
I’m not sure it even ever made sense.)  Another small step toward #433.

Add a test of is_behind_earth() with a Geometric

Also, clean up an awkward repeated `splitlines()` maneuver.  A small
preparation for more improvements in the direction of #433.

Risky: remove “observer_data” parameter from API

This is risky — strictly speaking, I should never change the public API
of any part of Skyfield because it could break user code.

But does there exist even a single user who has seen this parameter
named in the API docs (it’s never mentioned in the main docs nor in code
examples) who decided to read the code and started using it themselves?
My guess is, no, and so I am daring to attempt its deletion.

I plan to revert this if an issue is opened reporting user code that can
detect its absence.

Always ignore and never pass “observer_data” arg

Make a much more sound and deliberate decision about whether a position
deserves an `altaz()` method: by whether it can support it or not.  This
reveals that the `Geometric` class might have been misnamed, as it seems
more specific.  A small step for #433.
Add a TODO item

Cache GCRS of observer, and discard ObserverData

A big move: by caching an additional attribute on each position object,
we eliminate the need for an auxiliary data structure that was always
annoying.  This is progress towards #433.

Replace “negatives” with actual negative vectors

Instead of having a vector sum keep track of two separate lists of
“positive” and “negative” vectors, let’s purchase simplicity at the cost
of one level of indirection by defining a new “negated vector” wrapper
and filling a single list of vectors with both normal vectors and also
negated vectors where we need subtraction.

This momentarily compromises vector reprs and strs; hopefully repairs to
them will come within the next commit or two.

Introduce the idea of a negated vector function

Progress towards #433.  This will hopefully unlock a vast simplification
in the `VectorSum` that will then support the elimination of the final
`observer_data` attribute in use.

Destroy “snag” subsystem: teach Topos to refract

Instead of carrying the elevation of the observer in meters above sea
level around on the `observer_data` data structure, we here make
refraction a responsibility of the `Topos` — which is possible because
we are now carrying the `Topos` itself, rather than its mere string
description, as the `.center` of positions centered on it.  This both
provides a clear API for a planetary topos to plead ignorance of
atmospheric refraction (it can simply opt to not provide the method),
while removing the last use of the awkward and annoying “snag” subsystem
which now disappears with great rejoicing.  Progress towards #433.

Big refactoring: compute altaz rotation on demand

More progress towards #433.

* The position returned by `.observe()` now remembers the BCRS position
  object of its “center”, so that position’s vectors no longer need to
  be saved to the `observer_data`.

* We now prefer a position’s `.center` to be a live object like an Earth
  topos or planetary topos, not simply an opaque integer or string, so
  we can ask it for its altazimuth rotation matrix later if `.altaz()`
  is called.  Which gets rid of the need to precompute that matrix!

* Both Earth and planetary topos objects now act like frames and are
  able to return their `.rotation_at()` a particular time.

Remove “ephemeris” from observer_data

Progress towards #433.

Move barycentric pos & vel off of observer_data

The first progress in code towards #433.
After trying to write code, a decision for #433
Even more thoughts about #433
Further thoughts about #433
Two TODO ideas relevant to #433.
Update the version pin the docs illustrate

As prep for a simplified at(), remove old warning

This four-year-old warning from early 2016 guided users of Skyfield
≤0.6.1 through a breaking change in the API.  But as I now want to
simplify the `at()` / `_at()` system of calls (probably by removing
`_at()` methods entirely), it’s time to retire the warning, in the hope
that none of the remaining ≤0.6.1 installations (of which there might
not be many?) will upgrade without being able to figure out a way around
the breaking change.

This is work towards #433.
